headline: Vocational Education Overhaul Passes Final Reading, Dismantling Te Pūkenga
summary: Parliament saw the final passage of a landmark bill to dismantle the Te Pūkenga national polytechnic and restore regional institutions, a key government commitment. The legislative progress came as the government faced a barrage of criticism from the opposition over its two-year economic record, with intense debate focused on the cost of living, job losses in the construction sector, and ongoing public sector pay disputes.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Dismantle Te Pūkenga and Restore Regional Polytechnics Passes Final Reading
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This legislation reverses the previous government's merger of polytechnics, restoring local control over vocational training for trades like building, plumbing, and hairdressing.
topicSummaries.content: The Education and Training (Vocational Education and Training System) Amendment Bill passed its third and final reading, fulfilling the government's promise to disestablish the single national polytechnic, Te Pūkenga. The bill re-establishes regional polytechnics and creates new Industry Skills Boards to oversee work-based training. Minister for Vocational Education Penny Simmonds hailed it as a "great day for vocational education," arguing it restores local decision-making. However, the opposition parties—Labour, the Greens, and Te Pāti Māori—voted against the bill, raising serious concerns about its financial viability, the cost in jobs and courses, and a lack of industry support for the new model.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Penny Simmonds (National)
keyExchanges.quote: This is a great day for vocational education and training. That is all the wonderful people who build our roads and our houses, fix our cars, run our farms, plumb our bathrooms, cook for our restaurants, care for our people... those valuable people who are useful and drive our economy.

keyExchanges.speaker: Shanan Halbert (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: The promise that the National Government sold last election—to reintroduce regional autonomy for polytechnics—this bill does not achieve that... What is the real cost of this National Government's vocational reforms? The cost is jobs—hundreds of jobs in the vocational sector: gone. Campuses: gone. Courses and access to learning in our regional communities: gone.

topicSummaries.topic: Government and Opposition Clash Over Two-Year Economic Record
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The debate centered on whether New Zealanders are better or worse off after two years of the current government, focusing on key household concerns like job security and the cost of living.
topicSummaries.content: Marking two years since the government took office, Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins led a sustained attack on the Prime Minister's economic performance during Question Time. Hipkins highlighted a shrinking economy, rising unemployment, and an exodus of New Zealanders, questioning the Prime Minister's promise to "make things better." The government was also challenged on stalled pay negotiations with public sector workers like firefighters and nurses. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon defended his record, stating the government was "cleaning up the mess" left by the previous administration and pointing to progress in reducing crime, lowering inflation, and reforming education.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he think New Zealanders are feeling better off or worse off after two years of his leadership compared to before he became Prime Minister?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (National)
keyExchanges.quote: On the economic front, I'm proud of the fact that we've got Government spending under control. We didn't increase it 84 percent... But what we're doing is lowering inflation, lowering interest rates, getting the economy moving, and actually getting people back to work. And we're cleaning up the mess that that member left.

topicSummaries.topic: Education Bill Focusing on Achievement and University Free Speech Passes Second Reading
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This bill would legally make student achievement the top priority for school boards and require universities to adopt a code protecting freedom of expression on campus.
topicSummaries.content: The Education and Training Amendment Bill (No 2) passed its second reading, advancing significant changes to the education sector. Supported by the government coalition, the bill makes educational achievement the "paramount objective" for school boards and, in a move driven by the ACT party, compels universities to adopt a statement on freedom of expression. Labour and the Greens strongly opposed the bill, labeling it "government overreach" and an "imported culture war." Opposition speakers noted that only 13% of public submissions supported the bill in its entirety and argued the free speech provisions were an unnecessary intervention based on a single example involving former National Party leader Don Brash.

keyExchanges.speaker: Shanan Halbert (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Most concerning: when I asked the Minister if she had come across any examples, any evidence that validated this particular change... the only example that Minister Stanford could offer me was Don Brash.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dr Parmjeet Parmar (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: At the moment, what is happening because of those members sitting on the other side, our universities have been hijacked by the ideology, and we want to rescue universities from that, and that is why I am really pleased with this provision in this legislation.

topicSummaries.topic: Free Breast Screening Extended to Women Aged 70-74
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The change means an estimated 130,000 additional women will be eligible for free mammograms every two years, aiding in the early detection of breast cancer.
topicSummaries.content: The government announced that free breast screening will be extended to women aged 70 to 74, starting this month. Minister of Health Simeon Brown stated this was the first step in a nationwide rollout that will give women access to an additional two to three free mammograms over their lifetime. The government is supporting the extension by recruiting and training more staff, purchasing new equipment, and delivering four new mobile screening units to improve access for those in smaller towns and rural communities. The full implementation is expected to result in around 60 more breast cancers being detected early each year.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Announces Major Overhaul of Science Funding System
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The reform aims to simplify how public research funds are allocated by creating a single board, potentially speeding up investment in areas from health to technology.
topicSummaries.content: A major reform of the science and research funding system was announced by Minister of Science, Innovation and Technology, Dr Shane Reti. The government will create a single, independent board named 'Research Funding New Zealand' to replace a complex system of separate bodies. This new entity will consolidate the administration of major funds like the Marsden Fund, the Endeavour Fund, and health research from the Health Research Council. Dr Reti argued the current system is too bureaucratic and the change will create a simpler, faster, and more focused process for investing in research that grows the economy and improves New Zealanders' lives.

conclusion: The government successfully advanced its legislative agenda in education, while the opposition used the two-year anniversary to sharpen its attack on the government's economic stewardship.
